title: Expanding GST would 'boost economy', says Liberal MP
text:
The GST, which is administered by the federal government on behalf of the states, is becoming less effective as spending shifts to exempt items, including medical treatment and school fees.

Senator Smith's suggestion, made in The Australian Financial Review's Modest Member column on Monday, defies the leadership of his government, which is wary of opening up a political fight over tax reform.

"That's something we're not looking at – broadening the GST," Finance Minister Mathias Cormann told Sky News on Sunday.

'Negligible' benefit

Senator Cormann said the Coalition government considered expanding the GST a few years ago and economic analysis showed the benefit would be "negligible, if any".

The NSW push, which has support in Victoria, Western Australia and the ACT, ran into opposition from the South Australian Liberal government, which receives 57 per cent of its funding from Canberra but wants to be known for cutting taxes.

"The Marshall Liberal government was elected on a promise of not increasing the GST rate or expanding its base," Treasurer Rob Lucas told the Financial Review on Sunday. "That remains our policy."

But Senator Smith's comments, which follow similar remarks by NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet, suggest there is considerable support within the Liberal party for federal Treasurer Josh Frydenberg to pursue comprehensive Commonwealth-state tax reform to help lift the sluggish economy and waning productivity.

"When state and territory treasurers next meet Josh Frydenberg, they could abandon their calls for a boost in infrastructure spending and increases to Newstart and instead stand united in a call for tax reform, which starts with the removal of payroll taxes in exchange for a broader-based consumption tax," Senator Smith wrote.

"Payroll tax is universally regarded as a drag on economic activity and is ultimately paid by employees through lower wages and higher prices for consumers.

"Compensating state and territories for lost revenue could be achieved by broadening the GST or by a modest (but politically courageous) lift in the GST from 10 to 12.5 per cent."

Mr Perrottet last week called for the Morrison government to help states replace property stamp duties with a broad-based land tax and have a "conversation" about the GST.

Economists widely consider a broad-based consumption tax as less economically damaging than many other state taxes and have perennially called for the 10 per cent GST to be increased and/or broadened.

The federal government collects the $66 billion GST and distributes it to the states under a reform introduced by Liberal giants John Howard and Peter Costello in 2000.

Advertisement

Senator Smith said state and territory payroll tax on jobs had increased from $16.8 billion in 2008-09 to $24.4 billion in 2017-18.

The government is considering a business investment tax break, similar to Labor's election proposal for accelerated depreciation known as the Australian Investment Guarantee.

But Treasury advice issued to Mr Frydenberg before the May election and released publicly on Friday said such schemes favoured "old economy" capital-intensive industries, and "do little" to help labour-intensive firms.

Senator Cormann said the government would improve productivity and the economy through cutting business red tape, considering industrial relations changes, skills training, infrastructure investment, income tax cuts and making sure Australia remained an internationally competitive place to attract business investment.

When he was treasurer, Scott Morrison pushed internally for the government to consider reforming the GST, but was ultimately shot down by then prime minister Malcolm Turnbull.

The Coalition government ultimately did the opposite, caving in to pressure to make feminine hygiene products GST-free from January 2019.
description: Dean Smith's suggestion defies the leadership of his government, which is wary of opening up a political fight over tax reform.
